Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Hi Richard

My comments are:

1. The presence of location elements (that re=
present a specific schema design) in the web pages implies knowledge of imp=
lementation details, which goes against the grain of REST-ful architectures=
. Hence, to eliminate this, each web page should only contain (apart from o=
ther static, formatting and similar content) URIs to Resources. When you "c=
lick" on a URI, that "opens" another web page containing yet some more link=
s, and so on. How the web page is generated and how it obtains access to th=
e resources should be completely hidden from the "users". Thus, details of =
your schema or interfaces should not appear in your page design.

2. Given =
this, you may probably want to refactor your code so that the implementatio=
n details are moved out of the REST-ful "pages" (that represent the web ser=
vice you are making available).

Does this make sense, or am I missing the =
point?

Narayan Iyengar
 

  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: gattaca1=
5pcr 
  To: rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Thursday, June 12, 2003 1=
0:25 AM
  Subject: [rest-discuss] Nesting containers to a depth of ?


  Ca=
n anyone give me some advice on the following...

  I'm attempting to defin=
e REST-style interface for a system delivering 
  genomic map data.  

  Ce=
ntral to my design is the possibility of maps nesting one within 
  the oth=
er. Thus a map is, potentially, a composite of other maps. 
  Furthermore t=
here may be many levels of nesting.  My question is, how 
  can traversal u=
p an down this hierarchy be carried out in a REST-ful 
  manner? To illustr=
ate:

  http://bioinformatics/Map - returns details list of all maps

  <Ma=
ps>
        <Map href=3D"http://bioinformatics/Map/1">
              <label=
>Chromosome 1</label>
              <locations 
  href=3D"http://bioinforma=
tics/Map/1/Location"/>
        </Map>
        ... thousands of Map nodes ..=
.
        <Map href=3D"http://bioinformatics/Map/123">
              <label=
>Chromosome Z</label>
              <locations 
  href=3D"http://bioinforma=
tics/Map/1/Location"/>
        </Map>
  </Maps>
              

  http://bi=
oinformatics/Map/123 - returns a specific map
  <Map href=3D"http://bioinfo=
rmatics/Map/123">
        <label>Clone Z</label>
        <locations href=3D=
"http://bioinformatics/Map/123/Location"/>
  </Map>

  Let's suppose that h=
ttp://bioinformatics/Map/1 contains other maps 
  (e.g. http://bioinformati=
cs/Map/123). At present the way to retrieve 
  a list of the Maps contained=
 by http://bioinformatics/Map/1 is to 
  issue a GET to http://bioinformati=
cs/Map/1/Location. This returns a 
  list of positional Locations on the ma=
p (i.e coordinates). Embedded 
  within these locations are links to the pa=
rent map and the mappable 
  (i.e. the Map located at this position):

  <L=
ocations>
        <Location href=3D"...">
              .... 
        <Loca=
tion>
        .... thousands of Location nodes ...
        <Location href=
=3D"http://bioinformatics/Map/1/Location/10">
              <position>0.2</=
position>
              <map href=3D"http://bioinformatics/Map/1"/>
       =
       <mappable href=3D"http://bioinformatics/Map/123"/>
        </Locatio=
n>
  </Locations>

  Using the links provided in a Location node it should =
be possible to 
  traverse the graph of Maps.

  To my mind this is consist=
ent with the REST-ful idea of gradually 
  revealing data. Applications wis=
hing to use the data should certainly 
  be relatively simple to write and =
the consistency of the interface 
  appeals to me. However, this scheme has=
 the disadvantage of, 
  potentially, requiring many GET requests to traver=
se the graph. This 
  is mainly because the 'hierarchy' is not a simple tre=
e or forest - a 
  map be contained by more than one map. While mutliple GE=
T's shouldn't 
  be an issue for any client keeping a connection to the ser=
ver open, 
  I'd like to avoid any such requirement. Thus, I'd like to exte=
nd the 
  interface such that it is possible to traverse the graph of Maps,=
 
  bypassing the intermediate step of accessing Locations (the Location 
 =
 data may not be of much interest to a client in any case). Is there 
  any=
 sensible way to represent such a traversal? So far I've thought 
  of defi=
ning two new resources, Maps ( =3D Containers) and Mappables ( =3D 
  Conte=
nts), to make such traversal possible. By specifying in the URI 
  the reso=
urce to which movement should be relative, traversal up or 
  down the hier=
archy should be possible. For example:


  http://bionformatics/Maps/Map/12=
3  - would return a list of Maps that 
  contain http://bioinformatics/Map/=
123.

  and

  http://bioinformatics/Mappables/Map/1 - would return a list =
of all 
  the Maps contained by http://bioinformatics/Map/1


  Does this s=
cheme make sense? Although it seems distinctly un-REST 
  like, it does all=
ow me to do what I want to do. Mmmm... should I even 
  want to do what I w=
ant to do?

  Thanks in advance.


  Richard




        Yahoo! Groups Spon=
sor

 =
 rest-discuss-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com



  Your use of Yahoo! Groups is=
 subject to the Yahoo! Terms of Service.
